PowerShell

It is probably more useful than you think 😉

Before we begin...

How to Assess a Language

🚴 People

How well is the language supported?

🚵‍♂️ Platforms

Where can the language be used?

🧱 Paradigms

What programming paradigms does the language support?

What is PowerShell?

...a cross-platform (Windows, Linux, and macOS) automation and configuration tool/framework that works well with your existing tools and is optimized for dealing with structured data (e.g. JSON, CSV, XML, etc.), REST APIs, and object models. It includes a command-line shell, an associated scripting language and a framework for processing cmdlets. PowerShell GitHub Page

In other words, PowerShell is...

A user-focused typed programming language with native access to the host system and built-in support for structured data — available on Windows/Linux/Mac, pre-installed on Windows. J. Wohlgemuth

Examples

$credential = Get-ChildItem Cert:\CurrentUser\My | ? { $_.FriendlyName -like "Digital Signature" }

Get-ItemProperty HKLM:\SOFTWARE\WOW6432Node\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Uninstall\* |
    Select-Object DisplayName, DisplayVersion, Publisher, InstallDate |
    Sort-Object DisplayName |
    Where-Object { $_.DisplayName.Length -gt 0 } |
    Format-Table -AutoSize

Install-Module -Name Prelude -Scope CurrentUser

Why PowerShell?

🤖 Structured Data Support

PowerShell 🧡 dotnet

🧐 Developer Experience (DX)

🤠 Cross Platform Support

🎁 Open Source

🤖 Structured Data Support

✨ Built-in XML support ✨

<Barrel>
    <Monkey Action="no-see">🙈</Monkey>
    <Monkey Action="no-hear">🙉</Monkey>
    <Monkey Action="no-speak">🙊</Monkey>
</Barrel>

# import data
[XML]$data = Get-Content -Path data.xml

# get information
$data.Barrel.Monkey.Count | Write-Host

🤖 Structured Data Support

✨ Built-in CSV support ✨

name,power,race,super
Goku,9001,Saiyan,yes
Gohan,3042,Hybrid,yes
Vegeta,8999,Saiyan,yes
Trunks,8500,Hybrid,yes
Picollo,8001,Namekian,no
Krillin,1000,Human,no
Yamcha,1,Human,no

# import data
$data = ConvertFrom-Csv (Get-Content -Path data.csv)

# get column
$data.name | Write-Host

# get row
$data[0] | Write-Host

PowerShell 🧡 dotnet

PowerShell 🧡 dotnet

# import the code
Add-Type -TypeDefinition "
    using System;
    public class Calculator {
        public static double ToRadians(int degrees) {
            return degrees * (Math.PI / 180);
        }
    }
"

# use the code
[Calculator]::ToRadians(360)

✨ Also works with dynamic linked libraries ✨

🧐 Developer Experience (DX)

📚 Documentation / Get-Help <cmdlet>

🧰 Mature workflows (lint, test, build etc...)

🤩 Windows Terminal #cantBelieveItsNotLinux

🤠 Cross platform

docker run -it mcr.microsoft.com/powershell

🎁 Open Source

https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell

Case Study: Prelude

Install Prelude module

Install-Module -Name Prelude -Scope CurrentUser

Import Prelude module into terminal

Import-Module -Name Prelude

List all Prelude aliases

Get-Alias | ? { $_.Source -eq 'Prelude' }

List all Prelude functions

Get-Command -Module Prelude -CommandType Function

Case Study: Prelude

# Add the first 100 integers
$Sum = 1..100 | reduce { Param($a, $b) $a + $b }
# Add the first 100 integers again, but easier
$Sum = 1..100 | reduce -Add

# Calculate distance between two points on the earth
$Omaha = [Coordinate]@{ latitude = 41.25; longitude = -96 }
$SanDiego = [Coordinate]@{ latitude = 32.7157 ; longitude = -117.1611 }
$Distance = $Omaha - $SanDiego

# Fit a line to data with the method of least squares
$X = 1,-2,1,-1,1,0,1,1,1,2 | matrix 5,2
$Y = 0,0,1,1,3 | matrix 5,1
$B = $X.Transpose().Dot($X).Inverse().Dot($X.Transpose().Dot($Y))

Case Study: Prelude

✨ Lint with PSScriptAnalyzer

Invoke-ScriptAnalyzer -Path . -Settings settings.psd1 -Fix

📈 Test with Pester

Invoke-Pester -Configuration $Configuration

🚀 Deploy with PackageManagement

Publish-Module -Path $ModulePath -NuGetApiKey $NugetApiKey

People?

Active project, modules for many things, supports sustainable development

Platform?

Bundled with Windows, runs on Linux and Mac

Paradigms?

Prefers pipelines, lambda functions supported, cmdlets deal with objects
